That's the title on the cover of this month's National Geographic.
 
 A very good article for those that are interested. (Which unfortunately will likely only be those that already understand and accept the concept. :( )
 
 I'm going to post a few things that caught my eye and might spark a little debate.
 
 They cite the results of a Gallup poll, and quite frankly, I was astonished at its results -
 
 45% of Americans agreed with the statement "God created human beings pretty much in their present form sometime within the last 10,000 years or so"
 
 My only explanation, and I'm grasping at straws, is that people think of "modern humans" as being around for about 10,000 years, especially those with only cursory scientific knowledge.
 
 37% were satisfied in allowing room for both Darwin and God.
 
 Only 12% believed humans evolved from other life forms without the involvement of God.
 
 I really don't want to offend anyone here, but I thought Americans were supposed to be educated? It seems to me that even a rudimentary understanding of science and evolution would drastically alter these numbers.
 
 The really scary thing is that the're done this exact same poll in 1982, 1993, 1997, 1999, and again in 2004, and the percentage have only varied by very small margins. The creationist conviction - that God alone produced humans, has never fallen below 44%.
 
 There's always a lot of debate on "theory" in this section. Theory vs. fact.
 
 They point out that many of the things in life that we accept as fact and form basic parts of our everyday lives are actually scientific theory, some with less evidence to support them than evolution.
 
 The list includes -
 
 The Earth orbiting around the Sun rather than vice-versa
 Relativity  - E=mc2
 Atomic theory - the existance, structure and dynamics of atoms
 Continental drift - the movement of the Earth's crust as several large plates 
 Electricity - yes, electricity, is a theory, it is based on the the construct of electrons, tiny unobservable units of mass that contain positive and negative charges
 
 How many would question whether these ideas are "facts"?
 
 Beyond that, the article goes into the deveolpment of the theory via Darwin and Wallace, and the advancements in modern genetics. It also provides some very compelling evidence.
 
 Worth a read.
 
 Waxy
 
 P.S. The phrase "survival of the fittest" does not appear once in this 30 page article. :p

An important point that seems to have been missed is that the poll in question was not done by National Geographic. It was a Gallup poll that was apparently reported in NG. Gallup has been repeating these polls in essentially the same form every few years for decades. In spite of advances of science in those years, creationists seem to be as entrenched in their ignorance as ever.
 
 Other polls have arrived at similar conclusions. You have to suscribe to the Gallup site to see the results of their polls but they are reported elsewhere. Here is a discussion of the most recent Gallup poll, from 2001. This report is not comprehensive. Gallup asks more questions and then shows certain correlations between the data. George Gallup was himself a fundamentalist Christian and he expressed some disappointment with what the data showed.
 
 All of the polls showed that the more educated a responder was, the less likely they were to be a creationist. Besides being less educated, creationists also tend to be less affluent (understandable when one considers education), older, southern, more rural and female. I certainly hope that all of you are sophisticated enough to realize that data correlations do not necessarily indicate a causitive influence. Nevertheless, it was these correlations that caused Gallup himself to comment.
 
 Polls have also shown that about 95% of those holding a degree in science accept evolution rather than young earth creationism. The numbers are even higher, at about 99%, for biologists and geologists. Chemists have the highest number of creationists among their ranks, approaching 6%. I seem to recall that astronomers are next. I'm not sure how many of them are "creationists" as opposed to "young earth creationists." The bottom line is that the lists of "scientists" who accept creationism that have been put forward by creationist ministries are laughable. Few of the creationist scientists are biologists, and others hold law degrees, sociology degrees, hydrolics degrees, and the like. In answer, the National Center for Science Education began a list of evolutionary scientists named Steve - in honor of the then recently deceased Dr. Stephen Jay Gould. About 1% of the human population is named "Steve" in some form. Currently the Steve Project has 489 scientists with Ph.D. degrees in biology, geology, paleontology, or a related scientific field who suscribe to the statement (see below). The list includes Stephen Hawking, even though he is more a cosmologist than a biologist. How could the application of one of the greatest scientific minds of our day be refused?
 
 All of these scientists suscribe to the following statement:
 
Evolution is a vital, well-supported, unifying principle of the biological sciences, and the scientific evidence is overwhelmingly in favor of the idea that all living things share a common ancestry. Although there are legitimate debates about the patterns and processes of evolution, there is no serious scientific doubt that evolution occurred or that natural selection is a major mechanism in its occurrence. It is scientifically inappropriate and pedagogically irresponsible for creationist pseudoscience, including but not limited to "intelligent design," to be introduced into the science curricula of our nation's public schools.

 
 Waxy has pointed out some theories that are arrived at by inductive rather than deductive logic. He left out the theory of gravitation. We observe the effects of gravity but we have no idea why it works.
